title: The Hitchhiker — Day 1 Reading Check (Half 1, No Text)

metadata.note: Student text provided separately; assessment contains questions only.

items.prompt: Which detail best creates suspense early in the drama?

choices.text: Adams lists his age, looks, and license number.
Welles jokes about what the show will not include.
Adams warns the link with life could break soon.
Mother asks him to wire her when he reaches Hollywood.

items.prompt: Which inference is most supported by the repeated "fresh rain" on the man's shoulders?

choices.text: He keeps arriving soaked, as if storms follow him everywhere.
The hitchhiker is tied to something impossible or unnatural.
He works outdoors and hasn't changed after a shift.
He's signaling Adams to stop driving and pick him up.

items.prompt: How does the Pennsylvania Turnpike setting influence the plot?

choices.text: It gives Adams many safe places to pull over and rest.
It forces Adams to drive slowly most of the night.
It makes stopping unlikely, increasing fear and urgency.
It lets Adams easily question other drivers about the man.

items.prompt: What do Adams's actions at the Ohio detour most clearly reveal about his character?

choices.text: He stays relaxed and enjoys meeting strangers on the road.
He feels fear and lies to avoid the hitchhiker.
He is careless and ignores every warning he hears.
He is curious and tries to solve the mystery by talking.

items.prompt: Which line best supports the idea that Adams feels isolated?

choices.text: "I was in excellent spirits."
"I felt... unspeakably alone."
"It was a bright sunshiny afternoon."
"Nice night, isn't it?"

items.prompt: What is the MOST reasonable prediction at the end of Half 1?

choices.text: Adams will report the hitchhiker to the sheriff tomorrow.
Adams will decide the hitchhiker is harmless and forget him.
Adams will see him again and react more desperately.
Adams will return to Brooklyn instead of continuing west.

items.prompt: How do the sound directions (tires screeching, engine stalling, train whistle) mainly affect the drama?

choices.text: They replace the narrator by giving the listener all the facts.
They reveal inner thoughts more clearly than dialogue does.
They heighten tension by making danger feel immediate.
They slow the pace so the listener can catch every detail.

items.prompt: Which idea is implied by the mechanic's comments about hitchhikers on the turnpike?

choices.text: Hitchhikers are common because drivers have time to stop.
A hitchhiker there would be rare—and unsettling.
The mechanic regularly gives rides to travelers at night.
Most drivers prefer to pick up strangers for long rides.

items.prompt: In 3–5 sentences, explain how the drama builds suspense in Half 1 using setting and sound directions. Use one specific setting detail and one specific sound cue as evidence.
items.rubric_hint: Name a setting detail, name a sound cue, and explain how each increases tension/uncertainty.

rationales.rationale: A warning that life could end at any moment creates immediate danger and suspense.
Rain appearing where it shouldn’t suggests the man is not bound by normal reality.
A fast, isolated highway makes stopping feel unsafe, increasing fear and urgency.
Lying about his destination shows fear is driving his decisions and behavior.
This line directly states isolation, making it the strongest evidence of loneliness.
Sightings repeat and escalate, so another encounter and stronger panic is most likely.
Realistic sound cues make danger feel immediate, which heightens tension for listeners.
The mechanic stresses how unusual hitchhikers are there, making the sight alarming.
A strong response connects one setting detail and one sound cue to how suspense is built.
